title: Unspoken Ground Assumptions Of Discussion
summary:
Key ideas
- Writing something implies believing in it, which can have negative effects on free speech.
- There are different modes of presenting an argument, such as judge mode or lawyer mode.
- Explaining an underlying mechanism is different from describing how it works in the real world.
- Differentiating between pointing out a specific problem and contributing to an abstract discussion is important.
- Hypotheses are important for opening up discussion and gathering evidence.

Key learnings
- Logical fallacies can result from ambiguity in unspoken grounds.
- It may be difficult to avoid accusations of bias, just-so stories, or lack of evidence when presenting arguments.
- Consistently sticking to one side of a dichotomy may alleviate confusion.

Key questions
- Should we be more mindful of the implicit beliefs we present when we write about something?
- What are some other modes of presenting an argument besides judge mode and lawyer mode?
- How can we better distinguish between describing the real world and underlying mechanisms?
- How can we ensure that our arguments contribute to a problem instead of hindering it?
- Why do people tend to dismiss a hypothesis for political reasons, and how can we prevent this?
